text:
A few thoughts triggered by this discussion:

(a) <#C5T9GPWFL|thinking-together> was certainly not the right place for this, given how we used it. However, it’s not really clear to me either what belongs into <#C5T9GPWFL|thinking-together> and what into <#C5U3SEW6A|linking-together>. Maybe we should make it clearer that <#C5T9GPWFL|thinking-together> is for on-topic discussion and <#C5U3SEW6A|linking-together> for off-topic…? (That would not solve the actual problem in this thread, but could be a good idea anyway).

text: (c) Maybe we should have a dedicated #events channel, where we can also discuss who’s going to which event? I don’t think we should overdo it with too many channels and I’m not sure about this one.

text: (d) And maybe we’re big enough now to have a #meta channel to discuss exactly these things…?

text: I am no great lover of Slack, so I can't say what channel is for what.  For my part, the announcement seemed spammy because it doesn't have a Future Programming connection — except that we would hope that all kinds of people be programmers in the future and really in the present for that matter.

text: _I posted these as separate messages so you can express your opinion on each one with reactions. I’m not at all offended, if you :-1: any of these, and rather think it helps determining how much policy we need._

text: I wouldn't know what a diversity initiative would even entail. It seems like we're hardly a community of people as it stands, we're just people with a shared interest who aren't even really collaborating (from what I can see yet).

elements.text: I wouldn't know what a diversity initiative would even entail. It seems like we're hardly a community of people as it stands, we're just people with a shared interest who aren't even really collaborating (from what I can see yet).

text: For (d), let's make the #meta channel after a meta topic comes up again a time or two.

text:
Very interesting thread! When talking about systems, there’s the additional challenge that everything is fractal and systems contain other systems or form another system. When we talk about composing systems, we might have something like Unix pipes in mind, where we chain certain executables which can be written in different programming languages. And it is one thing to think more about the qualities these executables need to have to make this possible. But then this only works because there is the Unix philosophy and concept of pipes and filters and byte streams, which in itself is a (more abstract) system that has been designed to make this all work. 

It’s hard to figure out which level of abstraction we are currently thinking about as there will always be layers above and beneath it (e.g. the _What belongs into an OS?_ question). It almost feels like the fundamental problem to me: pinning our thoughts and ideas to a certain level, so we can start experimenting and noticing when we make assumptions or specify requirements for the layers above and beneath.

elements.text:
Very interesting thread! When talking about systems, there’s the additional challenge that everything is fractal and systems contain other systems or form another system. When we talk about composing systems, we might have something like Unix pipes in mind, where we chain certain executables which can be written in different programming languages. And it is one thing to think more about the qualities these executables need to have to make this possible. But then this only works because there is the Unix philosophy and concept of pipes and filters and byte streams, which in itself is a (more abstract) system that has been designed to make this all work. 

It’s hard to figure out which level of abstraction we are currently thinking about as there will always be layers above and beneath it (e.g. the
What belongs into an OS?

question). It almost feels like the fundamental problem to me: pinning our thoughts and ideas to a certain level, so we can start experimenting and noticing when we make assumptions or specify requirements for the layers above and beneath.

text: Yes! Everything seems like a system fractal. Every level is similar to every other level in some respects - definitely in the respect that each level is exactly as powerful as a Turing machine. What if we pin ourselves to an arbitrary level X - doesn't matter what it is - and we define an abstract model. Further, we design it such that if we go to Level X-1 or Level X+1, we find different details but with exactly the same abstract model. This is the idea of proof by induction and in recursive design ("make the parts have the same power as the whole" Bob Barton via Alan Kay). So if we define how Level X things compose and become Level X+1, but also require that the Level X+1 thus produced shares the same abstract model as X, we can now automatically go to Level X+2, employing the same composition rules. I don't know if this is feasible or even resonable, but it certainly is an idea that I find very interesting. There are faults here too, e.g. the 'single model fallacy' if there is such a term.

elements.text: Yes! Everything seems like a system fractal. Every level is similar to every other level in some respects - definitely in the respect that each level is exactly as powerful as a Turing machine. What if we pin ourselves to an arbitrary level X - doesn't matter what it is - and we define an abstract model. Further, we design it such that if we go to Level X-1 or Level X+1, we find different details but with exactly the same abstract model. This is the idea of proof by induction and in recursive design ("make the parts have the same power as the whole" Bob Barton via Alan Kay). So if we define how Level X things compose and become Level X+1, but also require that the Level X+1 thus produced shares the same abstract model as X, we can now automatically go to Level X+2, employing the same composition rules. I don't know if this is feasible or even resonable, but it certainly is an idea that I find very interesting. There are faults here too, e.g. the 'single model fallacy' if there is such a term.

text: <http://mgrf.de/vogo/>

My first reaction to this was.. "I'd rather just drag vertices around, thank you very much."

Then after giving it a moment to sink in, I realized.. this is actually quite powerful. In fact, it perfectly matches the abstraction behind SVG paths, so you could create this UI atop a traditional points-and-edges / bezier based vector graphics system as an alternative mode of interacting with the graphic. This approach is more structured, whereas the points-and-edges approach is more expressive. This might be a neat way to tie a toolset like Sketch or Illustrator into a structured graphical environment like Charticulator (<https://charticulator.com>) or Drawing Dynamic Visualizations (<https://vimeo.com/66085662>).

This approach is more structured, whereas the points-and-edges approach is more expressive. This might be a neat way to tie a toolset like Sketch or Illustrator into a structured graphical environment like Charticulator (
) or Drawing Dynamic Visualizations (

text: {aside: You could also tie this in to 3d graphics. The key detail that allows for this tying-in is that turtle graphics creates paths with a defined start and end (obviously), but that's the same way SVG-like vectors (including Flash) and 3d polygonal graphics are represented. You might look at a complex vector or mesh with lots of T intersections and think "that's free-form", but (with the exception of Figma [<https://www.figma.com>]), that's actually not the case. Points in a path are ordered according to a fairly strict ruleset that could be cleanly mapped to a turtle graphic representation.}

text:
What fun.  Matthias does begin, "Bret Victor inspired this thesis project."  Was able to reproduce my favorite Logo program:

```
to doit :r :dr
  fd 5
  rt :r
  doit :r + :dr :dr
end
```

text: CSG is similar to turtle graphics, yep. But I'm not sure there'd be the same nice, clean bidirectional mapping between the artistic representation (polygon meshes) and structured/semantic representation (procedural solids).

elements.text: CSG is similar to turtle graphics, yep. But I'm not sure there'd be the same nice, clean bidirectional mapping between the artistic representation (polygon meshes) and structured/semantic representation (procedural solids).

text: When working with CSG tools within a 3d editor that also offers free-form modelling (eg: 3DS Max, Maya, Modo, etc x 100), you run into the problem where you eventually need to destroy your procedural stack in order to achieve an artistic goal. That sucks. It'd be awfully nice to be able to represent free-form changes at the same semantic level as constructive/procedural changes. I'm sure that's been done, I just don't think it's filtered up to the level of 3d art tools.

text: A paper was just present at ICFP this week demonstrating a system that can take a mesh and infer a set of solid modeling operations. (Union, intersection, difference, scaling, translation of primitive geometric solids.) <https://homes.cs.washington.edu/~cnandi/docs/icfp18-cr.pdf>

elements.text: A paper was just present at ICFP this week demonstrating a system that can take a mesh and infer a set of solid modeling operations. (Union, intersection, difference, scaling, translation of primitive geometric solids.)

text: You can play with it here: <http://incarnate.uwplse.org/docs.html>

attachments.title: Reincarnate
attachments.text: Reincarnate is a project out of UW PLSE that aims to improve current 3D printing techniques using approaches from the programming languages community. We focus on design synthesis, optimizing compilation, and runtime monitoring. Now we have a compilation/synthesis tool availiable through our site allowing you to test out our 3D printing pipeline.

text: Hi all. I was recently introduced to Steve. I see I've stumbled across some like-minded folks here (i.e. "programming can be so much better!!!"). Like many of you, I'm a gentleman scientist (<https://nadiaeghbal.com/independent-research>), tinkering with language ideas that I'd love to use with real work. I just scanned this channel for interesting ideas and links, have 40 tabs open, and wonder if I'll get any sleep tonight. :slightly_smiling_face: Nice to be here.

attachments.title: The independent researcher
attachments.text: Adarsh Pandit recently introduced me to the concept of the “gentleman scientist”: a researcher who funds their work independently. After digging around a bit, I was fascinated to learn that independent researchers were fairly common in the 18th and 19th centuries.
